millsfield:images_texts:
Flying to Peiping
August 8th, 1935.
Dear Family:
I have been pretty much on the go ever since early Spring and as a
result my weary readers, have had a much needed rest which the author just now
would like to duplicate, sees little chance.
I an going to spend a few days with
the fanily just to get back on speaking terms and say to the children "ny how
you've grown !"
There is really not much to write about other than Chinese and Philippine
You wouldn't be interested and I am not qualified to discuss either
brand beyond saying that they compare very favorably with our own.
Philippines as in Missouri there are a certain number of patriots who are
vociferously willing to dedicate their lives to the public welfare, get their
names on a pay roll and their feet on a desk.
After the Philippine Commonwealth
is established the number of patriots will undoubtedly increase.
I had six weeks in Manila daring which time we secomplished a great
deal but did not secure favorable action on the franchise
which we tried to
secure from
the Philippine Legislature.
However, there seens to be no real.
opposition and we hope that the next session which is called for September 23rd
will approve our bill.
This is Thursday.
Got back to Shanghal. Monday afternoon.
Of cour se
there was plenty to do and I brought a lot of correspondence with me to read on
the plane and try to answer or dispose of in one way or another.
last night one of our best Chinese friends M.Y. Tang came by to see me
and learning that I was in a meeting wrote me a note.
It seems that his niece,
either actual or adopted, is going to attend some Catholie College in Webster
this Winter.
Her name is Eppy Changâ€¢
She is related to Mrs. T.V. Soong and comes
from one of the best families in China.
Debby and I had lunch with her almost a
year ago at a party which Mr. M.Y. Tang gave for Hebe and Catherine.
very charming girl, speaks English well and is very good looking.
I have written
letters of introduction for her to Ruth, Lucy, Mary Seott, Mrs. Beauregard
(Lindbergh Trophies) and to Archbishop Glenon. I hope very much that the
members of the St. Louis Bixby clan will show Miss Chang a good time - maybe have
her around for Sunday dimer or invite her to the Country Club some Saturday night.
If she dances as well as most Chinese girls you will fine your boy friends forming
Flying back to Shanghel Friday August 16th. I was booked to
return on Wednesday but at the request of one of our officials gave up my reserva-
tion in favor of an important passenger who had to be in Shanghai on Wednesday.
The Douglas transport flies up to Peiping on Tuesday, back on Wednesday and up
again on Saturday returning Sunday.
The other trip is made via Stinson up on
Thursday and back on Friday so, of course, I struck the small Stinson both ways.
Its funny how soon and how easily you become spoiled.
The Stinson nine hour
schedule used to seem de lux indeed as compared with. 44 hours by train. Now,
however, the Douglas 14 passenger liner with comfortable seats, no noise, 5 hour
schedule and steward serving tea, coffee, beer, sandwiches etc, makes the Stinson

- 2 -
seem like the wheel
barrow which we just flew over.
I have always wanted
tO
see
a wheel barrow with a sail and just now I spied one going along a narrow road.
It
was headed the opposite direction from our route which is another way of expressing
the
aviators favorite complaint - i.e., we have a head wind.
However, when you are
bucking a head wind you usually fly low and that is how it happened that I saw the
wheel barrow with full rigged square
of this "Kansas Yacht"
sail.
The coolie who was acting as helmsman
was stepping along at a lively rate while four people sat on
the barrow - two on each side of the "keel".
The
sail was about five feet high by
four feet wide.
I have seen pictures of these contraptions but this is the first
one I have ever
seen in actual use.
The "captain" did not have to worry like the
old Cape Cod captain who said he would not sail a brig because he was a
good
Caristian and the bible directed that no good Christian "could serve two masters."
I had a fine rest at Peiping.
When I arrived found Frances,
Bo and Ruth
were away
on a trip to Tai
Yuan Iu, Capital
of Shansi Province.
Shansi means
"west of the mountains" while Shantung means "east of the mountains".
In that section
there had been heavy rains with reports in Peiping that the rivers were overflowing
their banks, many ci ties wiped out,
bandits on
the loose and the usual number of
rumors which
thrive and gain momentun in a country where transportation and
communication is so uncertain.
Debby was quite worried but Sunday we received a
very welcome if inelegant telegram "hold your noses here we come".
And sure
enough Sunday evening about 7:30 the girls descended on us with eighteen bundles
of loot gathered in Shansi,
the packages ranging in size fron small
boxes to good
sized Shansi chests.
If we had locked the bathroom doors, I think the girls would
have traded all their plunder for the keys.
After one day in Peiping, they started
off early Tuesday morning for a trip to the Diamond Mountains of Korea. It will be
another interesting experience for them, and I'm wondering what the hige light will
be.
On the lastirly it was gun fire. The girls were crossing a big plain in Shansi
when they heard a loud mizzing noise over head, often repeated. In the distance
they could hear rifly fire.
Finally it dawned on them that the whizzing sound
was caused by bullets and they proceded in true negro fashion to say "feet carry
me away".
It turnd out that they were crossing a rifle range and probably stood
a much better chance of getting hit than if they had been the targets.
We are all very sad over the thought of Ruth going home early in
Septerber .
She has been a moal addition to our party in China and we*ll miss her.
I imagine
there will be times during her debutant winter when some boring dimmer
partner will catch a far away look in her eye and never quite know what the score is,
but I know too that she will cary on in St. Louis as she has here taking things
good, bad and indifferent, making the most of them all.
Nearing Shanghai nor so will wind up this letter - as ever
Narolo
